summary:
Although I am currently working as an educator, and to my sincere satisfaction so, I am never just one thing. I am a storyteller at heart yet I am also a journalist, an interviewer, a writer, a historian, a team player, a researcher and, indeed, a teacher. I thoroughly enjoy teaching and I believe in education as a meaningful proces of interaction in which many good things can happen on top of the transfer of knowledge and experience and the discovery and development of talents and personal skills.  

As an educator I appear in variety of guises. First of all, as a lecturer who explains aspects of communication processes and the skills and ethics that come with the exercise of professionalism in communication related jobs. Second, as a coach who monitors the discovery and development of professional skills on the part of students who work on individual or group assignments, regardless whether these concern first year efforts or graduation assignments. Thirdly, as a developer of novel lessons, courses and subjects to help keep programs up to speed with developments in a broad and dynamic labor market. Finally, I am a part of a team of educators who, together as well as alone, work tirelessly to offer programs to students that are interesting, useful, stimulating and fun to follow. 

I believe that careers are rarely linear tracks. At least, not consciously so. We live our lives in full interaction with slow and fast changing circumstances and try to make the most of opportunities and necessities while we enjoy them or complain about them, hardly or partly aware of the full impact of our own attitudes on what is to come next. Having grown up in a family of educators, I find myself now doing exactly that which I did not want to do for a long time yet have been quite familiar with all my life. Perhaps life is ironic in such things. Or perhaps not just so much. Either way, I pave my own way forward.

profile_positions.description: I have prepared guest lectures on topics closely related to my research on forms of interference with history textbooks in contemporary democracies. For seven consecutive years, often in early Sunday morning sessions, I found bright students from a broad variety of major programs as well as a broad variety in nationality willing to engage for a while with the tensions found at work in education system as these historically developed in a context of democracy. Still there? They were, often lively so.

profile_positions.description: I am currently writing my dissertation on censorship and other forms of control over/intervention with history textbooks in democratic societies. The project has an international comparative approach and features case study material from countries as diverse as the United States, Japan, India and the Netherlands. It is a subprject in the NWO sponsored project 'Censorship of Historical Thought' written and led by historian prof. Antoon de Baets from the University of Groningen.

profile_positions.description:
In May 2011 I was invited to run as candidate for the staff elections for the University Council. Having primarily campaigned as a representative for PhD's, I received enough support to have one of the twelve seats for staff members. The University Council meets in monthly cycles with the Executive Board of the University to discuss a wide range of policy issues. The Council has a number of rights in co-decision-making, such as advisory rights and the right of consent. The university's annual budget, for instance, requires the explicit consent by the Council. 
In 2013 I was re-elected for a second term. In 2015 I decided not to run again as my PhD contract would expire and I had not decided on any new position at the University. On the Council I have addressed a variety of topics, besides affairs of both bursary and employee PhD's, such internationalization, language policies, student housing, animal testing, the reports of the University Confidential Advisor and, currently, the plans to start a branch campus in Yantai, China.
profile_positions.title: Member University Council

profile_positions.description: As the news editor for the University of Groningen's autonomous (then printed, now website) newspaper 'UK'​, I was in charge of three to four pages offering university news. The job required me to assess and identify 'news', instruct students and freelancers to investigate and report, add reports to the website (in later years), discuss photography, cartoons and other illustrations with photographers and cartoonists and maintain contacts throughout the university. Conducting interviews and writing articles was included in the package.

profile_positions.description: As External Advisor to GRIN, a network of Groningen based PhD researchers, I discussed regularly with GRIN board members a variety of problems, complaints and concerns reported by Groningen Phd Candidates to GRIN. Topics were very diverse, e.g. related to contracts, housing issues, taxation problems and senistivities emanating from immigration status, the work environment and the working relationship with supervisors, Graduate Schools and the University at large. GRIN covers the full range of Groningen Faculties and Institutions, from Mathematics and Natural Sciences to Religious Studies and Economics and Business.
